clinical_study.brief_title: Rotator Cuff Surgical Outcomes in Women
clinical_study.official_title: Rotator Cuff Surgical Outcomes in Women

brief_summary.textblock: The overall purpose of this work is to use a prospective cohort study to examine patient-specific but shoulder-extrinsic factors and how they influence the results of rotator cuff surgery. There are undoubtedly many factors that play a role in patient outcome, however, this project will focus on three: the effect of gender on outcome, the effect of mood disorders and coping style on outcome, and the effect of patient height and reach on outcome after rotator cuff surgery. It is hypothesized that these factors will have a significant influence over outcomes.

Males, 35-75 receiving surgery for predominantly unilateral rotator cuff syndrome

study_pop.textblock: The participants for this study will be selected from the practice of three shoulder reconstruction surgeons in their embedded clinical research practice.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Referred for surgical treatment of predominantly unilateral rotator cuff syndrome
Exclusion Criteria:
- unable to speak or read English
- unable to complete 12 month follow-up
- significant cervicogenic arm and shoulder pain in the affected arm
- significant chronic pain diagnoses felt at least as likely to be the cause of the symptoms as the rotator cuff condition as evaluated by the surgeon
